json_ref: STATIC::Gen Info 1::Gen Info 1|Tenant Information|Tenant Entity Type
instructions:
Task: Given document_text containing one or more real estate lease-related documents (e.g., lease, amendments, estoppels, certificates), extract the tenant’s legal entity type and output it as a single, normalized short label.

What to extract
- Identify the legal entity type of the Tenant only (not the Landlord).
- Use all provided pages in document_text (primary lease, amendments, estoppels, exhibits) to find the clearest statement of the Tenant’s legal form. Prefer explicit recitals/signature blocks like: “Tenant: X, a [State] [entity type]” or a corporate designator in the tenant’s name.

Normalization rules (output must be EXACTLY one of these short labels; no extra words, punctuation, state names, or parentheses)
- LLC: if you see “LLC”, “L.L.C.”, “limited liability company”, “Ltd. Liability Co.”, etc.
  Example: “Mobily, LLC, a Texas limited liability company” → LLC
- Corporation: if you see “Inc.”, “Incorporated”, “Corp.”, “Corporation”, “Co., Inc.”, “Company, Inc.”, or if the entity is clearly a corporation.
  Example: “XYZ, Inc.” → Corporation
- LP: if you see “LP”, “L.P.”, “limited partnership”.
- LLP: if you see “LLP”, “L.L.P.”, “limited liability partnership”.
- Partnership: if you see “general partnership”, “partnership” (and not LP/LLP).
- Individual: if the tenant is a personal name with no business designator (e.g., “John A. Smith”) and documents do not indicate any registered entity.
- Trust: if explicitly a trust.
- Nonprofit: if explicitly a nonprofit corporation/organization and no other more specific label is required by ground truth.
- Government: if a governmental body or agency is the tenant.

Important interpretation guidance
- d/b/a doesn’t change entity type. Ignore the trade name. Example: “a Texas limited liability company d/b/a AT&T Authorized Retailer” → LLC.
- If multiple documents differ, prefer the most explicit legal description (e.g., “a [State] [entity type]”) over name styling alone.
- If the tenant name itself contains a clear designator (e.g., “... LLC”, “... Inc.”), that controls.
- If no explicit entity type is stated AND the tenant name looks like a business (not a person) with no designator, default to Corporation.
  Example: “AMADA SENIOR CARE MONMOUTH” (no designator, business-styled) → Corporation.
- If no explicit entity type is stated AND the tenant name looks like a personal name, use Individual.
- Do not output verbose phrases like “Texas limited liability company” or “Limited Liability Company (LLC)”. Only the exact normalized label (e.g., LLC).
- Do not return landlord’s entity type by mistake; ensure you are labeling the Tenant.
- Do not include explanations, reasons, or any extra text in the output—return only the label.

Edge cases and synonyms mapping
- LLC covers “LLC”, “L.L.C.”, and written-out “limited liability company”.
- Corporation covers “Inc.”, “Incorporated”, “Corp.”, “Corporation”. “Company” alone is NOT sufficient unless paired with Inc./Corp. or clearly corporate context; if business-styled with no designator, still default to Corporation per rule above.
- LP covers “Limited Partnership”; LLP covers “Limited Liability Partnership”.
- For professional corporations (PC, P.C.) and PLC, unless the ground truth requires a distinct label, map to Corporation.

Output format
- Return exactly one of the labels above (e.g., LLC, Corporation, LP, LLP, Partnership, Individual, Trust, Nonprofit, Government).
- No additional characters, spaces before/after, or explanatory text.

Examples
- “Tenant: MOBILY, LLC, a Texas limited liability company d/b/a AT&T Authorized Retailer” → LLC
- “Tenant: ALII INDUSTRIAL SERVICES LLC” → LLC
- “Tenant: AMADA SENIOR CARE MONMOUTH” (no designator; business-styled) → Corporation
